text:
Hi Nilearn,

I noticed that your function documentation is integrated seamlessly into your github hosted site, and I like that a lot.  :question:  How do you do that?

Best,

Vanessa
title: Question about nilearn.github.io

text:
Hi there,

On Sun, Dec 28, 2014 at 8:25 PM, vsoch notifications@github.com wrote:

> Hi Nilearn,
> 
> I noticed that your function documentation is integrated seamlessly into
> your github hosted site, and I like that a lot. [image: :question:]
> 
> Read about Sphinx: http://sphinx-doc.org/
> The doc is generated automatically from the function's docstring.
> 
> How do you do that?
> 
> Best,
> 
> Vanessa
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nilearn/nilearn/issues/332.

## 

DED
Cool, thanks!  I do know about sphinx, it's beautiful but just limited to python, I think.

On Sun, Dec 28, 2014 at 8:50 PM, vsoch notifications@github.com wrote:

> Cool, thanks! I do know about sphinx, it's beautiful but just limited to
> python, I think.
> 
> N.B: In languages like C, C++, etc. doxygen provides a feature with
> comparable strength.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nilearn/nilearn/issues/332#issuecomment-68217366.

## 

DED

Oh cool! I will check out doxygen.  I just used one called "roxygen2" for R:  http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/roxygen2/index.html

Now the naming makes sense, haha :)
